subject: Re: [junit] Testing Methods with Random Numbers
msgSnippet: ... There is exactly what we do to test behavior that uses randomness: we hide the ugly randomness behind an interface, then generate fixed sequences of data
messageBody:
Michael wrote:
> Hi. I was brainstorming and idea on the drive home from work tonight
> and realized I didn't know how to test something. This didn't come as
> a major shock, but I think I have an idea for a solution and I would
> like some devil's advocates :)
>
> Suppose the following class:
>
> public class SomeClass {
> public boolean doSomething(double x, double y) {
> double a = Math.random();
> double b = Math.random();
> return (x+a) > (y+b);
> }
> }
>
> Writing a test case for this is next to impossible because you do not
> know the results of the method beforehand. But what if there were an
> interface:
>
> public interface DoubleGenerator { public double nextDouble(); }
>
> that SomeClass depends on.
>
> public class SomeClass {
> private DoubleGenerator doubleGenerator;
> //setter method
>
> public boolean doSomething(double x, double y) {
> double a = doubleGenerator.nextDouble();
> double b = doubleGenerator.nextDouble();
> return (x+a) > (y+b);
> }
> }
>
> The implementation of DoubleGenerator in production code could be a
> wrapper around Math.random() and a testing implementation could allow
> you to set the sequence of doubles to return.
>
> You could also use java.util.Random instead of DoubleGenerator and
> subclass it to allow setting of the sequence, but I don't like having
> all the extra methods when SomeClass only needs one of them. However,
> having the extra methods allows for flexibility later. Opinions?

There is exactly what we do to test behavior that uses randomness: we
hide the ugly randomness behind an interface, then generate fixed
sequences of data in tests and use the random implementation in production.

> Also, is setting a DoubleGenerator with two doubles good practice? For
> now, doSomething() needs two doubles, but it may need three or four
> later. Is this "inside knowledge" bad practice when writing tests?

If you think it might need 3 or 4, then it should probably take a
collection of some kind. This is perfectly good practice in tests.

I find it nice when I independently discover something that is already
established practice. It tells me I'm on a good path.

Take care.
--
